habitat: Saprobic or weakly parasitic on decaying wood of old deciduous trees and shrubs, especially elder, beech, ash, spindle, Acer pseudoplatanus. Found worldwide in temperate and subtropical zones, growing year-round in clusters, often after rain.
shortDescription: An edible jelly fungus with ear-like, purplish-brown fruiting bodies. Tough, gelatinous, and elastic when fresh; hard and brittle when dry. Widely used in Asian soups and cuisine.
edibility: Edible when cooked, but must not be eaten raw. Mild flavor, jelly-like crunchy texture. Commonly consumed in Asia and Eastern Europe. Dried specimens can be rehydrated, swelling 3–4 times in size.
benefitsOrToxicity: Generally safe, with medicinal and nutritional benefits. Contains antibacterial, antitumor, antidiabetic, anticoagulant, antioxidant, antiviral, and cholesterol-lowering compounds. May negatively impact fertility; caution for pregnant or lactating women. Rehydrated mushrooms should be consumed within one day to avoid toxicity. Potential allergen for sensitive individuals.

identification.cap: Fruiting body up to 9 cm across, ~3 mm thick. Ear-shaped or cup-shaped, attached laterally, sometimes with a short stem. Upper surface reddish-tan to purplish brown, finely pilose, wrinkled with age. Undersurface lighter grey-brown, smooth to folded, sometimes veined.
identification.stem: Usually absent; sometimes with a very short lateral attachment.
identification.flesh: Thin, dense, cartilaginous, gelatinous, translucent, no strong odor.
identification.microscopicFeatures: Spores 12–14 × 4–5.5 μm, allantoid, hyaline; basidia 65–75 × 4–5 μm, cylindric, 3-septate; flesh with gelatinized hyphae 2–3 μm; abhymenial surface with projecting hyaline hairs 40–125 × 7.5–12.5 μm.

medicinalProperties: Traditionally used for throat and eye ailments. Demonstrated antibacterial, antitumor (diazane), anticoagulant, antioxidant, radioprotective (melanin pigments), antidiabetic, anti-inflammatory, anti-obesity, antiviral (sulfated polysaccharides), and cholesterol-lowering effects. Shows immunomodulatory properties and potential as an oral drug delivery system. Used historically in Europe as gargle for sore throats and in poultices.
note: First described as Tremella auricula by Linnaeus, later as Tremella auricula-judae by Bulliard. Renamed Exidia auricula-judae by Fries (1822) and finally placed in Auricularia by Schröter (1888). The epithet 'auricula-judae' means 'ear of Judas', linked to the legend of Judas Iscariot hanging from an elder tree.
